description: The Holy Trinity Cathedral, known as Sameba, is the third-tallest Eastern Orthodox cathedral in the world and one of the largest religious buildings globally by total area. Standing majestically on Elia Hill overlooking the Mtkvari River, this architectural marvel was built between 1995-2004 to commemorate 1,500 years of autocephaly of the Georgian Orthodox Church and 2,000 years of Christianity. With its soaring 87-meter central dome topped by a 7.5-meter gilded gold cross, Sameba represents Georgia's post-Soviet national and spiritual revival, serving as a powerful symbol of Georgian resilience, faith, and identity after decades of Soviet repression.
highlights: Third-tallest Eastern Orthodox cathedral in the world at 87.1 meters height (including cross)
Massive 3,000 square meter complex with main cathedral covering 2,380 square meters interior
Nine chapels total: five above ground and four underground, including chapels of the Archangels, John the Baptist, Saint Nino, Saint George, Saint Nicholas, the Twelve Apostles, and All Saints
Stunning synthesis of traditional Georgian church architecture from various historical periods with Byzantine influences
7.5-meter-tall gilded gold cross crowning the central dome, visible across Tbilisi's skyline
Panoramic views of Tbilisi from Elia Hill location
Trinity Cathedral Choir dedicated to preserving Georgian polyphonic singing traditions
Underground level with five additional chapels creating a unique multi-level worship space
The Sameba Sewing Shop where all church vestments and ceremonial banners are handmade
Armenian Pantheon located behind the church on the north-eastern side
tips: Visit both during day and at illuminated night for completely different atmospheric experiences
Best photography lighting is at sundown during blue hour, especially spectacular in winter
Dress modestly: skirts covering knees and head scarves required for women (available at entrance)
Attend Georgian liturgy services: 4:00 PM Saturday or 9:00 AM Sunday for authentic spiritual experience
Allow up to one hour to fully explore the cathedral, underground chapels, and grounds
Visit the Sameba Sewing Shop at the southern corner behind the stone chapel to see vestment-making
Explore the Armenian Pantheon behind the church (accessible via separate gate)
The walk up Elia Hill is steep but rewarding - wear comfortable shoes
Look for the coop with ducks, chickens, and peacocks near the entrance
Grounds are open 8 AM to 10 PM (gates locked at night), entry is completely free
vibe: Majestic, spiritually profound, and deeply symbolic - a powerful testament to Georgian faith and national identity that inspires awe through its monumental scale and serene sacred atmosphere
expectations: A massive, imposing Orthodox cathedral with traditional gold domes and crosses
Typical church interior with icons and religious artwork
Quiet, solemn religious space for prayer and contemplation
Historic ancient Georgian church from medieval times
Just another large church building in the city
reality: A surprisingly modern cathedral (2004) that masterfully synthesizes centuries of Georgian architectural traditions from 10th-11th century styles
One of the world's largest Orthodox cathedrals with nine chapels including a stunning underground level most visitors don't expect
A vibrant living symbol of Georgia's post-Soviet rebirth - conceived during opposition to USSR and built through Georgia's darkest civil war period
The entire complex includes monastery, theological academy, workshops, and even farm animals - it's a functioning religious community, not just a monument
Breathtaking hilltop location offering panoramic city views that transform dramatically between day and magical illuminated nights
unique_facts: The only large-scale construction project launched during Georgia's catastrophic 1990s period of civil war, inflation, and chaos - making its completion a remarkable achievement
Almost entirely funded by private contributions from Georgian citizens, not government money, despite official support from Presidents Shevardnadze and Saakashvili
The international architectural competition in 1989 received over 100 submissions before Archil Mindiashvili's design was selected
Foundation laid on November 23, 1995 (St. George's Day), exactly 9 years before consecration in 2004
Built according to precise norms of Georgian and Byzantine architecture from 10th-11th centuries, creating authentic historical synthesis
The complex contains historical monuments including a stone with one of the first known modern Georgian inscriptions and a structure housing a 6th-century cross
Home to the Trinity Cathedral Choir, specifically tasked by the Georgian Patriarch with preserving polyphonic singing - a UNESCO-recognized Georgian cultural treasure
The central dome alone reaches 87 meters (285 feet), making it visible from almost anywhere in Tbilisi
Five underground chapels create a hidden lower level that surprises most visitors expecting only the main cathedral space
surprises: It's only 21 years old (completed 2004), not centuries old as the traditional Byzantine-Georgian architecture might suggest
There's a working farm with ducks, chickens, and peacocks on the cathedral grounds - an unexpected rural touch in this monumental sacred space
The Sameba Sewing Shop behind the stone chapel where you can watch artisans creating all ceremonial vestments and banners by hand
The cathedral was a political statement as much as religious - emerging from 1989 Georgian opposition to the crumbling Soviet Union
Construction continued throughout Georgia's civil war and economic collapse when the country had almost no resources
An Armenian Pantheon sits behind the Orthodox Georgian cathedral, reflecting Tbilisi's multicultural religious heritage
The complex serves multiple functions: cathedral, monastery, theological seminary, academy, workshops, and Patriarch's residence all in one location
Night illumination completely transforms the experience - locals recommend visiting twice to see both versions
The steep hillside location means you get incredible exercise along with spiritual enrichment
Free entry despite being one of the world's most significant Orthodox cathedrals and a major pilgrimage destination
